did.unittitle: Walter B. Wriston papers
did.physdesc: 25.30 cubic ft., 1 bound volume, 109 digital objects
did.abstract: Walter B. Wriston retired as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Citicorp and its principal subsidiary, Citibank, N.A. on September 1, 1984, after having served as Chief Executive Officer for 17 years and in various other positions with the company for 38 years.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p:
Walter B. Wriston was born in Middletown, Connecticut, on August 3, 1919 to Dr. Henry Merritt Wriston and Ruth Colton Bigelow. Dr. Wriston (1889-1978) was president of Brown University from 1937-1955. Walter B. Wriston had an older sister Barbara. He graduated from Wesleyan University and the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University. Following a year's service as a U. S. State Department officer and a four-year tour with the U.S. Army during World War II, he joined Citibank in 1946 as a junior inspector in the Comptroller's Division.

Wriston was assigned to the National Division in 1949 and served in the division's Canadian and Transportation districts for seven years, becoming an Assistant Cashier in 1950, an Assistant Vice President in 1952 and a Vice President in 1954.

Wriston joined the bank's Overseas Division in 1956, heading the European District for three years, and was named a Senior Vice President in 1958. The following year he was made head of the Overseas Division and was appointed Executive Vice President in 1960. Wriston became President and Chief Executive Officer of the bank in 1967 and of the corporation when it was formed in 1968. He became Chairman in 1970. During his tenure as Chairman, he instituted a number of banking innovations such as the negotiable certificate of deposit, automatic teller machines (ATMs), and credit cards.

Wriston was Director of ICOS Corporation, Cygnus, Inc. and Vion Pharmaceuticals, Inc. He was Chairman of President Reagan's Economic Policy Advisory Board, a member and former Chairman of The Business Council, and a former co-Chairman and Policy committee member of the Business Roundtable. He was a Trustee of the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, a Life Governor of New York Presbyterian Hospital, and a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

Wriston retired as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Citicorp and its principal subsidiary, Citibank, N.A. on September 1, 1984, after having served as Chief Executive Officer for 17 years and in various other positions with the company for 38 years.

Mr. Wriston was awarded honorary degrees from Brown University, Columbia University, and Hamilton College. While at Citibank and after his retirement, he lectured at business schools and in other academic institutions. He spoke avidly on economics and the impact of information technology on the banking industry. He testified before U.S. Senate Committees representing Citibank and other banks.

Wriston was also a writer, whose work Risk and Other Four Letter Words, is a collection of essays published by Harper & Row, and The Twilight of Sovereignty published by Charles Scribner's Sons. Prior to his death in 2005, he was working on a third book, Bits, Bytes, and Balance Sheets: The New Economic Rules of Engagement In a Wireless World. The text will be published posthumously by Hoover Press.

Wriston married Kathryn Ann Dineen in March, 1968. His first wife, the Barbara Brengle, died in 1966. He had one daughter, Catherine W. Quintal (Mrs. Richard M.), and two grandchildren, Christopher Wriston Quintal and Barbara Catherine Quintal. He was a member of the Links Club, University Club, River Club of New York, Sky Club, Ocean Club of Ocean Ridge, Florida and the Palm Beach Bath and Tennis Club. Wriston passed away on January 19, 2005 in New York City.

Prior to his death, Wriston was honored with the Medal of Freedom by President George W. Bush on June 23, 2004.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
This collection contains materials from Walter B. Wriston's office at Citibank on Park Avenue in New York. The bulk of the material dates to the 1980s and 1990s and includes both paper and electronic media.

The majority of the materials consist of source materials for and drafts of Wriston's three books "Risk and Other Four-Letter Words" (1986), "The Twilight of Sovereignty: How the Information Revolution is Transforming Our World" (1992) and "Bites, Bytes, & Balance Sheets: The New Economic Rules of Engagement In a Wireless World" (2007). Also included are a nearly comprehensive collection of speeches and articles about banking, finance, and technology written by Wriston throughout his career. Wriston's career and interests are also documented in a substantial collection of audiovisual media and photographs. Subject files contain organizational records, special event materials, Wriston's 'inspiration' files, memorial and funereal material, and extensive correspondence. Awards recognizing Wriston's accomplishments include the Presidential Medal of Freedom (2004), as well a letter from President Ronald Reagan and letters of condolence from President George W. Bush.

Also included are the computer spreadsheets which document the original order of the computer files on each of Wriston's three computers. For more information about how the computer print-outs were processed, see the series-level note for series 008, as well as collection documentation. Collection documentation also includes the inventory of the Wriston archival material retained by the Citibank Archives.

accessrestrict.p: Some of the records in this collection are restricted. See the DCA's General Policy on Access for more information about access to records.
This collection is partially processed. Some materials may be restricted and not available for research. Contact the DCA for more information.

userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections. Please see the DCA's policy on Copyright and Fair Use for more information.

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Mr. Wriston's wife, Kathryn Dineen Wriston, and his family. The collection consists of materials from his office at Citibank on Park Avenue in New York. They were arranged by Kurt Willet and shipped to the archives via UPS in three installments. The files from his office and personal computers were extracted and burned to a CD-ROM which was also included in the collection. His wife, Kathryn Wriston, later set another package containing two copies of "The Twilight of Sovereignty: How the Information Revolution is Transforming Our World" and "Risk & Other Four-Letter Words."

processinfo.p:
Series 001: Speeches

-Michelle Romero, 2008: The final drafts and the back-up copies had spiral bindings which were removed as a conservation measure. If items were bound with rusting paper clips, the paper clips were replaced with non-rusting ones. The paper clips were kept in the collection to maintain the original order and the context of the documents.

-Laura Cutter, 2009: Material processed into series 001 in 2009 was arranged in a second chronological run at the end of the series. Most of this material consisted of printed out computer files. All computer files were originally arranged by the computer they were extracted from, then alphabetically. Materials were removed from this arrangement and added to existing series in order to provide access. Final publication titles are included in brackets, followed by Wriston's original computer file names. The dates included as part of the file names were preserved, but when that date was wrong, the archivist added the actual date. These computer files were also copied to CDs by Kathryn Wriston and are included with duplicate media in the green barcodes.

Series 002: Books (Processing Notes)

-Michelle Romero, 2008: Included in this series are printouts of Wriston's computer files for "The Twilight of Sovereignty." The files were extracted from his computers and saved on a CD-ROM, "CD_Rom_WBW_Computer Files." The printouts of the chapters are arranged chronologically. The date for the materials was derived from the last date it was modified.

-Laura Cutter, 2009: Material processed into series 002 in 2009 was arranged in a second chronological run at the end of the series, beginning with 'Twilight of Sovereignty', published in 1992, followed by 'Bits, Bytes, and Balance Sheets', published in posthumously in 2007. Within each book, manuscripts and chapter drafts are filed first (chronologically when possible), followed by source material, then publication material and correspondence. Most of this material consisted of printed out computer files. All computer files were originally arranged by the computer they were extracted from, then alphabetically. Materials were removed from this arrangement and added to existing series in order to provide access. Final publication titles are included in brackets, followed by Wriston's original computer file names. These computer files were also copied to CDs by Kathryn Wriston and are included with duplicate media in the green barcodes.

Series 003: Articles and Interviews (Processing Notes)

-Michelle Romero, 2008: Thermal faxes and newspaper clippings were photocopied to ensure the longevity of the article content.

Laura Cutter, 2009: Material processed into series 003 in 2009 was arranged in a second chronological run at the end of the series. Most of this material consisted of printed out computer files. All computer files were originally arranged by the computer they were extracted from, then alphabetically. Materials were removed from this arrangement and added to existing series in order to provide access. Final publication titles are included in brackets, followed by Wriston's original computer file names. The dates included as part of the file names were preserved, but when that date was wrong, the archivist added the actual date. These computer files were also copied to CDs by Kathryn Wriston and are included with duplicate media in the green barcodes.

Series 004: Audio-visual material (Processing Notes)

-Michelle Romero, 2009: The CD-ROM containing files extracted from Wriston's computers were migrated to the DCA's servers. A number of the file types were so old the files were resaved as plain text files.

-Laura Cutter, 2009: Material processed into series 004 in 2009 was added in a second run at the end of the series, arranged by media type, then chronologically. The types of media consist of videocassettes, audiocassettes, microcassettes, CDs, and DVDs. The vast majority of this material was already included in the collection. Therefore, duplicate materials were separated from new, unique items. If the donated material was of preservation standard (ie: DVD or CD) and the duplicate material in the collection was not (ie: audiocassette or videocassette), then the DVD or CD was added to the collection regardless of duplication. Unique material was added regardless of format. Materials added to the collection were rehoused for preservation purposes and all information on original cases or boxes was transferred to the new enclosures. Duplicate audiovisual material has been inventoried but remains unprocessed and is stored in the green barcodes to await a disposition decision. Also housed with this material are the CD-Rs created by Kathryn Wriston from the files extracted from Walter B. Wriston's three computers. All of the files on these CD-Rs were printed out by Kathryn Wriston and processed into the collection. Four CD-Rs with personal financial information were returned to Kathryn Wriston in December 2009.

Series 005: Subject Files (Processing Notes)

-Laura Cutter, 2009: Material processed into series 005 in 2009 was added as a second alphabetical run at the end of the series. Some of the subject files in this series include printed out files extracted from Wriston's computer. When files could not be identified, they were included with the original file title followed by the term 'unidentified fragment' in brackets. Some printed-out computer files, such as correspondence, include explanatory information in brackets, as well as the original computer file title supplied by Wriston. There is also a substantial amount of paper material in this series that is not printed from Wriston's computers. In these cases, original titles have been retained or new titles have been supplied by the archivist in brackets.

Series 006: Photographs (Processing Notes)

-Laura Cutter 2009: The photographs prints in the collection were created from eight CDs included in the first accession of Wriston material. However, not all of the CD files have accompanying photographic prints. There are seventy-seven image files stored on the eight CDs. There are thirty-nine photographic prints. The CDs were sent to the Digital Collections and Archives in five installments, separately from the rest of the collection. The CDs labeled "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 1"; "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 2"; "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 3"; and "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 4" were received on July 23, 2007. The CD labeled "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 5" was received on August 2, 2007. The CD labeled "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 6" was received on August 6, 2007. The CD labeled "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 7" was received on August 16, 2007. The CD labeled "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 8" was received on September 20, 2007.

The photographic prints in series 006 are arranged chronologically and the CDs are arranged as received. For each print, the CD name and the file name of the image is listed in the notes field at the item level. Any copyright information (to Harwood Studio, Citicorp/Citigroup, the "New York Times," James Leynse, or Douglas Levere) is also listed in the notes field. Two prints, one of Walter B. Wriston with President Richard M. Nixon and members of the National Commission on Productivity and one of Walter and Kathryn Wriston with president Jimmy Carter, were received in October 2009 and are housed separately in an oversize box. These prints to not correspond to images on the CDs.

Media and Electronic Records

Many of Wriston's writings and speeches exist in electronic format on the DCA's servers. Some files were originally electronic and extracted from Wriston's computers, while others were scanned and formatted using optical character recognition software. Much of this material is available through the Tufts Digital Library (TDL). A number of the file types were so old the files were resaved as plain text files. A substantial amount of the audiovisual media, principally Wriston's television appearances, is also stored on the DCA's servers, but is not available on the TDL. Many of the printed out documents from the 2009 accession are duplicated on the CD 'MS134.004.030.00008 CD_Rom_WBW_Computer Files', processed by Michelle Romero. They are also duplicated on the CDs of extracted files donated 2009, which remain unprocessed and stored in the green barcodes.

did.unittitle: Speeches

arrangement.p: The speeches are arranged chronologically. Materials accessioned and processed in 2009 are arranged in a second chronological run at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
This series contains speeches written by Walter B. Wriston. The speeches span from 1951-2003 with the bulk of the speeches from the 1980s. The speeches were produced for an assortment of engagements, such as Citigroup/Citibank events and meetings; lectures and commencement ceremonies at schools and universities; retirement dinners and introductions; Business Council meetings; testimony before U.S. Federal/State Committees; testimony or remarks at the European and U.S. Chamber of Commerce; Committee and Board of Trustee meetings; conferences; club meetings; association meetings; and the Bank Forum. Pamphlet versions of some speeches were published by First National City Bank (Citibank/Citigroup) and are included with the corresponding speech. In addition, there is material relating to speaking engagements, such as correspondence, conference packets, travel arrangements, thank you letters, slides, and notes.

Speech titles are followed by the date on which Wriston gave a particular speech. For speeches that included a date range, the date on which Wriston actually gave the speech is in the notes field. The folders often contain multiple copies of the speeches including rough drafts, final drafts, and back-up copies. Some of the speeches are printed out files extracted from Wriston's computer. Titles in brackets indicate a final publication title followed by Wriston's original computer file name. Wriston's original computer file names were preserved. When a file date did not correspond to the actual date of the speech, the date of the speech was added.

c01.accessrestrict: This series is open for research.

arrangement.p: The materials in this series are arranged chronologically by book. Materials accessioned and processed in 2009 are arranged in a second chronological run at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
This series contains material relating to Walter B. Wriston's three published books: "Risk and Other Four-Letter Words" (1986), "The Twilight of Sovereignty: How the Information Revolution is Transforming Our World" (1992) and "Bites, Bytes, & Balance Sheets: The New Economic Rules of Engagement In a Wireless World" (2007). Wriston frequently spoke and wrote about banking, the impact of information technology, and other economic issues. He used his speeches and articles to form the basis of his books.

Material in this series includes multiple drafts of each book and drafts of individual chapters, as well as material related to the books, such as source material, reviews, and correspondence. Materials relating to each book were kept together and have been grouped by type, such as complete drafts, chapter drafts, source material, publication information, and correspondence. Material in box 042 relates to publication rights, contracts, royalties, and finances for Wriston's books and is restricted for 75 years.

"Risk and Other Four-Letter Words"

Wriston's first book, "Risk & Other Four-Letter Words" was published in 1986 by Harper and Row Publishers, now HarperCollins. It is an edited compilation of his speeches on contemporary banking and economic issues. The collection includes two reviews for the book and a bound copy of the text. The speeches used as the source material for this text are included in series 001.

"The Twilight of Sovereignty"

Wriston's second book, "The Twilight of Sovereignty: How the Information Revolution is Transforming Our World" was first published in September 1992 by Charles Scribner's Sons. This book is also referenced by its original working title, "The Information Revolution." Material in the collection includes the 1987 book proposal and various drafts from 1987 to 1992. Some drafts have handwritten notations and corrections. The drafts are arranged chronologically when possible. Some of the draft materials are printed out files extracted from Wriston's computers. Some of these files are saved on a CD-ROM titled "CD_Rom_WBW_Computer Files", which is located in series 004.

In addition to drafts of the book, the "Twilight" material also contains correspondence between Wriston and his publishers from 1990-1993. The bulk of these letters are from Edward "Ned" T. Chase, senior editor at Charles Scribner's Sons. These letters document discussions of the book's index and book jacket, as well as plans for promoting the book and requests for reviews. Chase also sent a number of current newspaper and journal articles to incorporate into the text. Wriston's other correspondents from Scribner's include Hamilton Cain, assistant editor; Bill Goldstein, senior editor; and Charles Flowers, assistant editor. There is also a memo from Richard Vigilante, editor of "The City Journal", who assisted in editing the book. Other correspondence, ranging from 1992-1996, are primarily letters of thanks for autographed copies of the book and letters from people who read the book or saw Wriston during press junkets. Wriston's sixth grade teacher, Martha Sorensen, also sent a letter commenting on the book.

Reviews for "The Twilight of Sovereignty" are arranged chronologically from 1992-1993. The reviews consist of photocopies, torn out pages, and bound volumes of journals and newspapers.

"Bites, Bytes, & Balance Sheets"

Wriston's third and final book, "Bits, Bytes, and Balance Sheets: The New Economic Rules of Engagement In a New Wireless World" was published posthumously by Hoover Institution Press in 2007. Material in the collection includes drafts of the manuscript and of individual chapters, as well as source material, publication material, and correspondence. Some of the draft materials are printed out files extracted from Wriston's computer and saved on a CD-ROM titled "CD_Rom_WBW_Computer Files", which is located in series 004.

Prior to Wriston's death in 2005, he was working on a new manuscript entitled, "The Quick and the Dead: The New Economic Rules of Engagement For A Wired (and Wireless) World". In 2000, Wriston was in the process of editing the manuscript and locating a publisher when, due to illness, the book was put on hold. After Wriston's death, his wife Kathryn Wriston hired editor John McCarty and Kurt Willett to complete the manuscript. The book was extended to ten chapters and re-titled, "Bits, Bytes, And Balance Sheets: The New Economic Rules of Engagement In a New Wireless World." The posthumous additions to the manuscript were created from the speeches written by Wriston from 1994-2002. Although Wriston had been ill, he continued to write speeches and, when possible, attend speaking engagements. The Honorable George P. Shultz, a close friend of Wriston's, wrote a forward for the revised manuscript and Kathryn Wriston wrote an afterword. The Hoover Institution Press annotated "Bits, Bytes, and Balance Sheets" with updated economic data prior to publication.

Articles and Interviews

arrangement.p: The articles and interviews in this series are divided into articles mentioning Walter Wriston, interviews with Mr. Wriston, and articles by Walter Wriston. They are arranged chronologically. Materials accessioned and processed in 2009 are arranged in a second chronological run at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
This series contains interviews and articles written by, about, or mentioning Walter B. Wriston from 1955-2004. Material in the collection includes original published articles, as well as photocopies and drafts by Wriston. Also included is Wriston's correspondence with editors and/or producers, discussing the particulars of an article or interview. There are also drafts of articles by Wriston which were submitted for publication but were not published. Wriston was interviewed for various programs, including Face the Nation, Meet the Press, Lou Dobbs Moneyline, Lou Dobbs Tonight, Bloomberg Television, and Wall Street Week with Louis Rukeyser. Articles by and about Wriston were published in many periodicals, including American Banker, American Politics, Barron's, Business Week, the Cato Journal, Chief Executive, Christian Science Monitor, City Journal, Computers in Banking, the Economist, Emerging Market Strategy, the Far Eastern Economic Review, Finance, the Fletcher Forum of World Affairs, Forbes, Foreign Affairs, Fortune, the Harvard Business Review, Intelligencer, New York Newsday Forum, the New York Observer, the New York Times, Reuters World, Time, the Wall Street Journal, and the Washington Post.

Folders are labeled with the name of the article, the author(s), the title of the publication or program, and the date range of the folder or, if the article is the only item in the folder, the date of the article. Some of the speeches are printed out files extracted from Wriston's computer. Titles in brackets indicate a final publication title followed by Wriston's original computer file name. Wriston's original computer file names were preserved including their dates. When a file date did not correspond to the actual date of the article or interview, the actual date was added.

c01.accessrestrict: This series is open for research.

arrangement.p: The audiovisual materials in this series are arranged by media type, then chronologically, with material from the 2009 donation added as a second run at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
This series contains audiovisual media, predominately DVDs and CDs, of interviews and speeches by Walter B. Wriston between 1982-2005. Also included are DVDs collected by Wriston about economics, banking, and the various organizations with which he was affiliated. This series includes Wriston's interviews on the Idea Channel with Bob Chitester, Herbert Pardes, Hugh Carey, Robert D. McTeer, Jr., Charles Brunie, and Peter W. Huber. Wriston also appeared on Face the Nation, Meet the Press, Lou Dobbs Tonight, Wall Street Week with Louis Rukeyser, Telecommunications & Information Revolution, and a PBS show called "Electric Money." Wriston's Presidential Medal of Freedom Award is commemorated by a DVD of the presentation ceremony and a DVD created by Citigroup, honoring Wriston. Also included is a DVD of Wriston's convocation speech for Tufts University's Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy in 2003. Wriston was unable to attend the ceremony and his speech was read by Academic Dean Lisa Lynch.

There is also a CD-ROM containing copies of files extracted from Wriston's computers in New York City and Connecticut. The majority of the files are drafts of Wriston's books "Twilight of Sovereignty" and "Bites, Bytes, and Balance Sheets", as well as drafts of speeches, articles, and letters. The files are in IBM and MAC formats and the date of last modification ranges from 1989-2006. In addition to Wriston's computer files, the CD-ROM includes spreadsheets and word files created by Kurt Willett to assist in the transfer of documents and the creation of a website dedicated to Walter B. Wriston. The spreadsheets list the file name, a description of the file, the date the file was last modified, the size, the original location of the file, and file type.

c01.accessrestrict: This series is open for research.

arrangement.p: Materials in this series are arranged alphabetically by subject, except correspondence, which is subdivided by topic, then alphabetically, with material donated in 2009 is arranged in a second alphabetical run at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
This series consists of subject files relating to variety of people, organizations, events, and topics. Citibank/ Citigroup materials include press releases, correspondence and annual reports. Records relating to Municipal Union/Financial Leaders Group (MUFLG) include meeting minutes and articles from the New York Times and the Wall Street Journal. The group was established to assist in the resolution of the New York City fiscal crisis of 1975. Presidential Medal of Freedom Award materials include White House and Citigroup press releases; reception materials; and congratulatory correspondence, emails, and phone calls. Obituaries, tributes, memorial plans, and condolence letters for Walter B. Wriston are contained in this series. There is a significant amount of material relating to Walter Wriston's father, Henry Merritt Wriston, including book reviews, memorial tributes, correspondence, and press releases. Wriston's files of quotations, which he called "inspiration files" and used in his writings and speeches, are also included. Unidentified writings by Wriston, primarily printed out from his computer files, have been included here if they could not be assigned to a specific series.

This series also includes extensive correspondence. Single letters are filed individually and correspondence is subdivided by topic, organization or person. Correspondents include Alan Greenspan, George P. Shultz, Richard Vigilante, Rose and Milton Friedman, as well as Presidential holiday cards from Ronald and Nancy Reagan. Organization-related correspondence includes American Academy of Arts & Sciences, the Business Council, the Cato Institute, Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, and the White House. Topical correspondence includes condolences, political correspondence, and retirement.

c01.accessrestrict: This series is open for research.

arrangement.p: The photographic prints in this series are arranged chronologically. CDs are arranged as received.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
This series contains images of Walter B. Wriston, as well as his family, colleagues, and home in Connecticut from 1925-2004.

The photographic prints in the collection were created from eight CDs included in the first accession of Wriston material (though not every CD image file has a corresponding print). For each print, the CD name and the file name of the image is listed in the notes field. Some of the images are copyrighted to Harwood Studio, Citicorp/Citigroup, the "New York Times," James Leynse, and Douglas Levere.

Two prints, one of Walter B. Wriston with President Richard M. Nixon and members of the National Commission on Productivity and one of Walter and Kathryn Wriston with president Jimmy Carter, were received in October 2009 and are housed separately in an oversize box. They do not correspond with images on any CDs.

c01.accessrestrict: This series is open for research.

did.unittitle: Awards and Recognitions

arrangement.p: The materials in this series are arranged as received.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains awards and other materials recognizing the service and achievements of Walter B. Wriston. Wriston's awards include the Order of the Golden Heart conferred by President Ferdinand E. Marcos and Mrs. Imelda R. Marcos in 1971 and the Presidential Medal of Freedom conferred by President George W. Bush in 2004. There is also a framed collage of material from Wriston's 1961 visit to the White House to meet with President John F. Kennedy. There is a framed congratulatory letter from President Ronald Reagan presented to Wriston upon his retirement from Citibank, as well as a framed photograph of Wriston with President Reagan. There are two framed letters of condolence from President George W. Bush, written to Kathryn Wriston upon the death of Walter Wriston.

c01.accessrestrict: This series is open for research.

Computer Spreadsheets

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series consists of spreadsheets printed and annotated by Kathryn Wriston which document the original order of the files on each of the three computers ('CT MAC', 'NYC MAC', and 'IBM') used by Walter B. Wriston, as well as relevant metadata such as file size, type, date, etc. Printed-out computer files were arranged into other series for ease of access, but each printed-out computer file can be intellectually traced back to its original computer context using the spreadsheets. Drafts of the same document may appear on multiple computers, but do not always have the same title or file name. Individual documents were organized using the final publication title, when available. However, each folder also retains the original file title which, in turn, corresponds to the title listed in the spreadsheets.

c01.accessrestrict: This series is open for research.

did.unittitle: Computer Spreadsheets
